html: vegastrike/Vega-Strike-Engine-Source#505
text: https://github.com/vegastrike/Vega-Strike-Engine-Source/pull/505

html:
A brief into into the lib_damage parts:

CoreVector - a struct that holds an x,y,z float values. We don't use Vector here because that would expose too much of the main engine for no reason. All we need are these three floats.

Damage - a struct that holds multiple types of damage and how much of it has already been expanded. This replaces a whole bunch of hacks, primarily negative for non-lethal damage. As this structs goes through shield, armor and hull, damage is reduced from it and transferred to them. Currently, it is also used for vulnerability. What layer is vulnerable to what damage. For example, phase damage does not damage the shield and so keeps on going deeper.

DamageableObject - something that can be damaged and be destroyed. Holds multiple DamageableLayers in a vector.

DamageableLayer - a layer within an object. Typically shield/armor/hull. Holds multiple DamageableFacets in a vector. The layer also evaluates which facet receives the damage.

DamageableFacet- if layer is shield, a facet is front, rear, etc. Holds a health object.

Health - holds the maximum health, current health etc.
text:
A brief into into the lib_damage parts:

**CoreVector** - a struct that holds an x,y,z float values. We don't use Vector here because that would expose too much of the main engine for no reason. All we need are these three floats.

**Damage** - a struct that holds multiple types of damage and how much of it has already been expanded. This replaces a whole bunch of hacks, primarily negative for non-lethal damage. As this structs goes through shield, armor and hull, damage is reduced from it and transferred to them. Currently, it is also used for vulnerability. What layer is vulnerable to what damage. For example, phase damage does not damage the shield and so keeps on going deeper.

**DamageableObject** - something that can be damaged and be destroyed. Holds multiple DamageableLayers in a vector.

**DamageableLayer** - a layer within an object. Typically shield/armor/hull. Holds multiple DamageableFacets in a vector. The layer also evaluates which facet receives the damage.

**DamageableFacet**- if layer is shield, a facet is front, rear, etc. Holds a health object.

**Health** - holds the maximum health, current health etc.

html:
A few questions, in no particular order:
Is this going to handle regeneration (e.g. for shields) as a case of "negative" damage, or is there a different abstraction that will be used here?
text:
A few questions, in no particular order:
Is this going to handle regeneration (e.g. for shields) as a case of "negative" damage, or is there a different abstraction that will be used here?

html: How is system (i.e. weapons, flight computer, engines, etc.) damage going to be integrated? If all systems have a well-defined coordinate/volume/etc. in modelspace, that simplifies some things, but the point of contact, if it's coming from the collision of the weapon and vessel, is generally going to be on the shield/hull no matter what.... assuming that the collision coordinate is good in the first place
text: How is system (i.e. weapons, flight computer, engines, etc.) damage going to be integrated? If all systems have a well-defined coordinate/volume/etc. in modelspace, that simplifies some things, but the point of contact, if it's coming from the collision of the weapon and vessel, is generally going to be on the shield/hull no matter what.... assuming that the collision coordinate is good in the first place

html: Should it be a contact coordinate, or a contact coordinate and a normal? That could allow more interesting penetrating damage/understanding of what is in the path of the damage
text: Should it be a contact coordinate, or a contact coordinate and a normal? That could allow more interesting penetrating damage/understanding of what is in the path of the damage

html: If we're going to have a more data-abstracted collection of damage types (strongly approve vs. old hacks! Also opens things up for general data sets not having to map into just {+normal,+phase}/tractor{+,-}/repulsor{-,+}/system{-,-} paradigm, or to have multiple types of shields, etc.) it's not 100% clear to me that the damage should be carrying the vulnerability information - if the damage just carries a type, the interaction between damage type A and dameageableLayer type B could be a static table lookup.  In the same vein, I'd like to be able to see the damage be a vector of type-value pairs, not a fixed-size struct. This would also allow different weapons to have different orderings on the application of damage types to model complex warheads
text: If we're going to have a more data-abstracted collection of damage types (strongly approve vs. old hacks! Also opens things up for general data sets not having to map into just {+normal,+phase}/tractor{+,-}/repulsor{-,+}/system{-,-} paradigm, or to have multiple types of shields, etc.) it's not 100% clear to me that the damage should be carrying the vulnerability information - if the damage just carries a type, the interaction between damage type A and dameageableLayer type B could be a static table lookup.  In the same vein, I'd like to be able to see the damage be a vector of type-value pairs, not a fixed-size struct. This would also allow different weapons to have different orderings on the application of damage types to model complex warheads

html: Looking at damageable_factory.cpp -- if I'm reading this right - does this assume that all armor and shield facets have the same strength? This doesn't seem desirable - asymmetric armoring/shielding should be supported
text: Looking at damageable_factory.cpp -- if I'm reading this right - does this assume that all armor and shield facets have the same strength? This doesn't seem desirable - asymmetric armoring/shielding should be supported

html: Also looks like it's forcing the armor and shields to have the same facet configuration
text: Also looks like it's forcing the armor and shields to have the same facet configuration

html:
Is this going to handle regeneration (e.g. for shields) as a case of "negative" damage
It should. Just hit something with a negative damage of certain type and fix something.

How is system (i.e. weapons, flight computer, engines, etc.) damage going to be integrated?
It isn't yet. I started something preliminary (see DamageableObject) but it's too specific for the library. It may be better to handle this at the engine level. Call DealDamage from unit and the then look at the results as they are stored in the Damage struct for clues on how to deal damage to internal systems.

If all systems have a well-defined coordinate/volume/etc. in modelspace

That's really out of scope for the rather humble design of mine. Once you're into the hull, anything can break. You can model something better in a separate library but I'm not sure it belongs in this one.

Also opens things up for general data sets not having to map into...

Exactly. Add blast effect (torque?). Medic ships patching armor. Refueling in flight. etc.

it's not 100% clear to me that the damage should be carrying the vulnerability information

It's not. I'm reusing the struct (I shouldn't) and storing it in Health. The values there are typically between 0 and 1. 0 means you bypass. 1 means all damage is first dealt to this layer.

I'd like to be able to see the damage be a vector of type-value pairs

It might be possible but let's consider this for a later phase. This is hard enough.

Note that we have to make sure that we expose the right things to the graphics layer to do blending of the damage texture

Ideally, the Damage struct or maybe something like ResultingDamage struct would be used to inform the graphics and audio and whatever of the results.

Should it be a contact coordinate, or a contact coordinate and a normal?

I don't even know what that means. Contact is the coordinates at the skin. Normal is as you progress inward? I have no idea how to do this.

all armor and shield facets have the same strength?

No. It's possible some factory methods are incomplete/incorrect. It's still a WIP and I'm adding methods as I'm converting the game.

it's forcing the armor and shields to have the same facet configuration

Also no. Right now hull is one. Armor is eight and shield is variable from two to eight.
text:
> Is this going to handle regeneration (e.g. for shields) as a case of "negative" damage
It should. Just hit something with a negative damage of certain type and fix something.

> How is system (i.e. weapons, flight computer, engines, etc.) damage going to be integrated?
It isn't yet. I started something preliminary (see DamageableObject) but it's too specific for the library. It may be better  to handle this at the engine level. Call DealDamage from unit and the then look at the results as they are stored in the Damage struct for clues on how to deal damage to internal systems.

> If all systems have a well-defined coordinate/volume/etc. in modelspace

That's really out of scope for the rather humble design of mine. Once you're into the hull, anything can break. You can model something better in a separate library but I'm not sure it belongs in this one.

> Also opens things up for general data sets not having to map into...

Exactly. Add blast effect (torque?). Medic ships patching armor. Refueling in flight. etc.

> it's not 100% clear to me that the damage should be carrying the vulnerability information

It's not. I'm reusing the struct (I shouldn't) and storing it in Health. The values there are typically between 0 and 1. 0 means you bypass. 1 means all damage is first dealt to this layer.

>  I'd like to be able to see the damage be a vector of type-value pairs

It might be possible but let's consider this for a later phase. This is hard enough.

> Note that we have to make sure that we expose the right things to the graphics layer to do blending of the damage texture

Ideally, the Damage struct or maybe something like ResultingDamage struct would be used to inform the graphics and audio and whatever of the results.

> Should it be a contact coordinate, or a contact coordinate and a normal? 

I don't even know what that means. Contact is the coordinates at the skin. Normal is as you progress inward? I have no idea how to do this. 

> all armor and shield facets have the same strength?

No. It's possible some factory methods are incomplete/incorrect. It's still a WIP and I'm adding methods as I'm converting the game.

> it's forcing the armor and shields to have the same facet configuration

Also no. Right now hull is one. Armor is eight and shield is variable from two to eight.

html: @ministerofinformation would a contact vector/line be more appropriate than a coordinate? E.g a laser would pierce along the whole line, burning through; a missile would penetrate to a depth based on velocity; both would be impacted through by the initial point of contact (coordinate) where the vector/line would pass through, but then the velocity of the object (ship, asteroid, etc) would also come into play to determine if the damage accumulated at a single spot or was lessened due to movement across a surface... I'm assuming we already modelled that kind of things previously and this library is just pulling together what was previously modelled, with some improvements; so this is more about the interface/terms.

html: @BenjamenMeyer - we didn't model movement across a surface during a single timestep; if a beam weapon moves across a target, then the damage will be spread across whatever shield/armor facets are hit in specific timesteps
text: @BenjamenMeyer - we didn't model movement across a surface during a single timestep; if a beam weapon moves across a target, then the damage will be spread across whatever shield/armor facets are hit in specific timesteps

html: We also didn't model geometry-penetrating damage (i.e. a beam going in one end of a target and out the other)
text: We also didn't model geometry-penetrating damage (i.e. a beam going in one end of a target and out the other)

html:
I'm still working on this, but wanted to raise a new issue. There are functions in the engine that are exposed to the python side. These make it more difficult to refactor, as we need to keep them around or change the python as well. For example, damageable.cpp has DealDamageToHull. Now this function is no longer needed in the engine for the normal flow but the real problem is that it returns a percent of something. It does this so the calling function can evaluate something. There are probably better ways to do this.
I'd appreciate some guidance on how best to tackle this.
text:
I'm still working on this, but wanted to raise a new issue. There are functions in the engine that are exposed to the python side. These make it more difficult to refactor, as we need to keep them around or change the python as well. For example, damageable.cpp has DealDamageToHull. Now this function is no longer needed in the engine for the normal flow but the real problem is that it returns a percent of something. It does this so the calling function can evaluate something. There are probably better ways to do this. 
I'd appreciate some guidance on how best to tackle this.

html: @royfalk I'd stub them out and try to return the same thing, add a comment about it no longer being needed so we can refactor it out of the Python side too at a later date.
text: @royfalk I'd stub them out and try to return the same thing, add a comment about it no longer being needed so we can refactor it out of the Python side too at a later date.

html:
Again requesting some help, primarily from @ministerofinformation .

  1. If I use a pugilist and disruptor against Oswald, is he supposed to never run out of shield? Is it Oswald or do I need to multiply damage by 5.4 or something?
  2. Can you also point me in the direction of the VDU? I'll try now on my own but I don't think I touched it but clearly something broke.

Also a general call for testers. @BenjamenMeyer such a major change should really go into a beta branch of some sort. Asking normal users to clone my repo just to test isn't reasonable.

html: Here are the statlines on Oswald and the initial player ship from testing back in June: "Pulling up Oswald in the debugger, looks like his ship has 500 VSU of hull, 500 armor on each of 8 facings and 2000 shield with 100/s recharge; for comparison, the player starts with 500 hull, 100 armor, 150 shield with 8 recharge/s"

</Beam>

I switched the PR from draft. I've played the game for about an hour. It is mostly stable. I had one crash where intelligent.h:51 had a sigsegv. Best guess is a race condition. Object calling getAIState() got deallocated. Damage is also OK. I can see my armor going down nicely as I'm hit.
I'll start working on comments and would appreciate a review. I realise some of you have already reviewed the code, but back then I released it more as a design review than code review.
I would also appreciate testing and bug reports.

html:
This is a bit of a discussion, some of which, I know less about. But here goes anyway:

  1. DealDamageToHull is a bad API. Unlike its name, it doesn't damage the hull but armor and hull.
  2. Originally (0.53), this called DealDamageToHullReturnArmor and it affected both.
  3. I split it into the Damageable implementation which dealt with actual subtraction of damage (1st part) and left the rest of the code (2nd part) which dealt with everything else.

I am not the person I was when I wrote this a few months ago and neither is the code (thank god). This wasn't originally a virtual function. I added it (incorrectly) as part of my attempts to untangle the unit mess. The current implementation of the API simply applies the damage as phase damage and bypasses the shields by calling ApplyDamage.

As a side discussion, I intentionally made lib_damage use DealDamage throughout and Damageable (which is part of vs_engine) use ApplyDamage. The first functions propagate damage and nothing else and the second plays sounds, lights shields, etc. I made the decision to name them differently but you could make the opposite argument.
text:
This is a bit of a discussion, some of which, I know less about. But here goes anyway:
1. DealDamageToHull is a bad API. Unlike its name, it doesn't damage the hull but armor and hull.
2. Originally (0.53), this called DealDamageToHullReturnArmor and it affected both.
3. I split it into the Damageable implementation which dealt with actual subtraction of damage (1st part) and left the rest of the code (2nd part) which dealt with everything else.

I am not the person I was when I wrote this a few months ago and neither is the code (thank god).  This wasn't originally a virtual function. I added it (incorrectly) as part of my attempts to untangle the unit mess. The current implementation of the API simply applies the damage as phase damage and bypasses the shields by calling ApplyDamage.

As a side discussion, I intentionally made lib_damage use DealDamage throughout and Damageable (which is part of vs_engine) use ApplyDamage. The first functions propagate damage and nothing else and the second plays sounds, lights shields, etc. I made the decision to name them differently but you could make the opposite argument.

html: @royfalk Hmm. I see. Perhaps there isn't a reason to worry about whether DealDamageToHull is virtual or not, then.
text: @royfalk Hmm. I see. Perhaps there isn't a reason to worry about whether DealDamageToHull is virtual or not, then.

html:
This will teach me to hit enter when I'm just getting started :)
I'll cut this short and say the original API is less than optimal. When we decide to make breaking changes to the API (and we should), I'd suggest we take a hard look at what's currently available and change it.
I understand the theory behind virtual (more or less) but am less familiar with the nuances of planning ahead by adding virtual. If you guys think this is the way to go, even though it's a single function, I'll add it.
text:
This will teach me to hit enter when I'm just getting started :)
I'll cut this short and say the original API is less than optimal. When we decide to make breaking changes to the API (and we should), I'd suggest we take a hard look at what's currently available and change it. 
I understand the theory behind virtual (more or less) but am less familiar with the nuances of planning ahead by adding virtual. If you guys think this is the way to go, even though it's a single function, I'll add it.

html:
I'm following it with interest, even though I struggle with cmake. I'm going to push a commit which may solve the linker error. I've noticed a few months ago that the linux compiler "magically" knows about certain functions even though the relevant headers are not included. I thought it was because it's including a whole bunch of other headers which eventually include the headers in question but never actually tested this.
I hope that's the case.
text:

html: if you can do things like breaking libdamage into its own directory structure that would be helpful as I'd like to break down Cmake into multiple files where we push all the common stuff to a main file, and then it includes sub-directories with their own files; and even separate out libraries like libdamage into parallel sections to help isolate them - though we'll see how well that works for the current tree. (It's what I normally do; but current implementation might make that harder to do...will see)
text: if you can do things like breaking libdamage into its own directory structure that would be helpful as I'd like to break down Cmake into multiple files where we push all the common stuff to a main file, and then it includes sub-directories with their own files; and even separate out libraries like libdamage into parallel sections to help isolate them - though we'll see how well that works for the current tree. Three things I'd like to discuss:
  1. @stephengtuggy am I supposed to fix the mac compilation as well? It's failing on
    `/Users/runner/work/Vega-Strike-Engine-Source/Vega-Strike-Engine-Source/engine/src/vsfilesystem.cpp:757:19: error: no matching function for call to 'scandir'
     int ret = scandir( selectcurrentdir.c_str(), &dirlist, selectdirs, 0 );` and it looks like it may be an OS version thing.
  2. @BenjamenMeyer please tell me I don't have to clean Drawable::Split. I just moved it from unit_generic and did not touch it otherwise.
  3. If no additional code changes are required, I'd like to freeze this PR and start testing it over a few days - just playing and looking for breaking stuff. If all goes well, I hope to merge it by the weekend. Of course, other people are welcome to test as well.

html:
It is now more than two months since I started this PR. At last count it has 2300 added lines of code and 1900 removed. It also consistently has bugs in the cockpit, showing hull damage where there is none, shields on planets and jump points, etc. More worrying, the game is unstable and crashes often due to changes to minor functions such as flickerDamage. I actually haven't played it seriously since I started coding so I don't know if this is normal or not.

At this point, I doubt I could figure out the bugs on my own and I'm a bit burnt. I'm calling it and closing the PR. I will start working minor changes to damage code from the PR as well as other code.
text:
It is now more than two months since I started this PR. At last count it has 2300 added lines of code and 1900 removed. It also consistently has bugs in the cockpit, showing hull damage where there is none, shields on planets and jump points, etc. More worrying, the game is unstable and crashes often due to changes to minor functions such as flickerDamage. I actually haven't played it seriously since I started coding so I don't know if this is normal or not.

At this point, I doubt I could figure out the bugs on my own and I'm a bit burnt. I'm calling it and closing the PR. I will start working minor changes to damage code from the PR as well as other code.

html: A more incremental approach should hopefully avoid the issues I encountered.

html:
Well, I guess all I needed was a few weeks rest.

This last round of fixes sorted nearly everything out.
At this point I think we can either merge this to master or to some kind of beta for people to test.

I've done extensive testing both during development and after. Here are the remaining issues:

  • Can't kill asteroids when firing at them with guns. It used to be possible.
  • I once fired a missile at a ship in an asteroid field and the whole field detonated. I had a similar issue some time ago in another PR.
  • There was an issue where the shield turned off at some point and wouldn't turn on. Not sure why and not reproduced in later tests.
  • When ejecting, the pilot has better radar than skyscope01. It has colors and stuff. It should have less.
  • Escort ships of bounty missions don't turn red when I blow the bounty ship up. They are marked as hostile and yellow. This may be due to fear. I did notice them running away.
text:
Well, I guess all I needed was a few weeks rest.

This last round of fixes sorted nearly everything out.
At this point I think we can either merge this to master or to some kind of beta for people to test.

I've done extensive testing both during development and after. Here are the remaining issues:
- Can't kill asteroids when firing at them with guns. It used to be possible.
- I once fired a missile at a ship in an asteroid field and the whole field detonated. I had a similar issue some time ago in another PR.
- There was an issue where the shield turned off at some point and wouldn't turn on. Not sure why and not reproduced in later tests.
- When ejecting, the pilot has better radar than skyscope01. It has colors and stuff. It should have less.
- Escort ships of bounty missions don't turn red when I blow the bounty ship up. They are marked as hostile and yellow. This may be due to fear. I did notice them running away.

html: @royfalk that's excellent news!
text: @royfalk that's excellent news!

html: The pilot has always had better radar after ejecting. At least in my experience.
text: The pilot has always had better radar after ejecting. At least in my experience.

html: And yeah, you're probably right about what's going on with the escort ships.
text: And yeah, you're probably right about what's going on with the escort ships.
